There are several options for the pressure relief mechanism in your air compressor valve design. Each has its own advantages and disadvantages, so consider the specific requirements of your invention and the desired user experience when selecting a mechanism. Here are a few options to consider:

1. Spring-loaded piston valve:
A spring-loaded piston valve works by using a spring to hold a piston against a valve seat. When the pressure in the tire reaches the set value, the force on the piston overcomes the spring force, causing the piston to move and open the valve. This allows excess air to escape, preventing further inflation. The advantages of this mechanism are its simplicity, reliability, and low cost. However, it may be less accurate than other options, particularly when dealing with low pressure differences.
2. Diaphragm valve:
A diaphragm valve uses a flexible diaphragm to separate the high-pressure and low-pressure sides of the valve. As the pressure in the tire increases, the diaphragm deforms and eventually triggers the valve to open, releasing excess air. Diaphragm valves offer good accuracy and are resistant to wear and tear, but they may be more expensive and complex to manufacture compared to other options.
3. Solenoid valve with pressure sensor:
In this setup, a pressure sensor continuously monitors the tire pressure and sends the information to a microcontroller. When the desired pressure is reached, the microcontroller activates a solenoid valve, which opens to release excess air. This design offers high accuracy and the ability to incorporate additional features, such as digital pressure display and user alerts. However, it is more complex, requires a power source, and may be more expensive than other options.
4. Ball-and-spring relief valve:
A ball-and-spring relief valve uses a ball held against a valve seat by a spring. When the tire pressure reaches the desired value, the force exerted on the ball overcomes the spring force, causing the ball to move away from the seat and open the valve. This allows excess air to escape, preventing further inflation. This type of mechanism is simple and cost-effective, but it may be less accurate and more prone to wear and tear than other options.

When selecting a pressure relief mechanism for your air compressor valve, consider factors such as accuracy, reliability, manufacturing cost, and ease of use. It may be helpful to create and test prototypes of different mechanisms to determine which one best meets your design requirements and user needs.
